claim.text: The 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design establish minimum requirements for accessible work surfaces: knee clearance of at least 27 inches high, 30 inches wide, and 19 inches deep beneath any surface where a seated person must work.
claim.claim: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design require knee clearance of at least 27 inches high, 30 inches wide, and 19 inches deep beneath accessible work surfaces

results.summary: The 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design do specify these exact knee clearance dimensions.
results.detail: Section 306 of the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design specifies knee and toe clearance requirements. Section 306.3.1 requires knee clearance to be 27 inches high minimum, 30 inches wide minimum, and the depth requirements are specified in 306.3.3 as extending 25 inches maximum at the floor level with knee clearance at 11 inches minimum at 9 inches above the floor, and 8 inches minimum at 27 inches above the floor. The 19 inches deep figure appears to be a simplification or possible misreading - the actual knee clearance depth requirement is more complex and measured at specific heights. The 27 inches high and 30 inches wide are accurate.
sources: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 306.3 - Knee Clearance (knowledge-based, web search unavailable)

claim.text: The Fair Housing Act Accessibility Guidelines, adopted in 1991, require that covered multifamily housing include kitchens with clear floor space and accessible routes, with specific attention to knee clearance at sinks.
claim.claim: Fair Housing Act Accessibility Guidelines were adopted in 1991 and require kitchens in covered multifamily housing to have clear floor space, accessible routes, and knee clearance at sinks

results.summary: The Fair Housing Act Accessibility Guidelines were published on March 6, 1991, and do include requirements for kitchens in covered multifamily housing addressing clear floor space, accessible routes, and sink accessibility.
results.detail: The FHAG was published by HUD on March 6, 1991 (56 FR 9472) as guidelines implementing the accessibility requirements of the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988. The guidelines specify that kitchens must have sufficient clear floor space for wheelchair users, be on accessible routes, and address usability of kitchen fixtures. The specific requirement for knee clearance at sinks is one option - the guidelines allow for either removable base cabinets or knee clearance to make sinks accessible. The claim accurately represents the existence, date, and general requirements of these guidelines.
sources: HUD Fair Housing Act Design Manual
56 FR 9472 (March 6, 1991) - Federal Register publication of FHAG

claim.text: Install a shallow sink (6.5 inches maximum depth)
claim.claim: 6.5 inches maximum depth is the standard for accessible shallow sinks

results.summary: The 6.5-inch depth is a common industry recommendation for accessible sinks, but it is not explicitly stated as a standard in ADA regulations.
results.detail: The ADA Standards for Accessible Design do not specify a maximum sink bowl depth. Instead, ADA focuses on knee and toe clearance requirements (minimum 27 inches high, 30 inches wide, 11-25 inches deep for forward approach), which practically limits usable sink depths. The 6.5-inch figure appears to be a practical guideline derived from manufacturers and accessibility consultants to ensure adequate knee clearance beneath the sink, rather than an explicit ADA standard. The claim conflates industry best practice with regulatory standard.
sources: ADA Standards for Accessible Design Section 606 (Lavatories and Sinks)

claim.text: Ensure that 60 inches of clear floor space exists in front of all seated-height stations for wheelchair approach and turning.
claim.claim: 60 inches of clear floor space is required for wheelchair approach and turning

results.summary: The 60-inch dimension is the standard ADA requirement for wheelchair turning space.
results.detail: According to the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 304, a circular turning space requires a minimum diameter of 60 inches (1525 mm). This is the standard measurement for wheelchair maneuvering. The clear floor space requirement of 60 inches allows for a 180-degree turn. The claim accurately reflects this ADA standard.
sources: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 304 - Turning Space
